original_poem:
on s’habitue aux écritures penchées où il n’y a plus d’enfants, lorsqu’ils sont devenus grands et que leurs yeux reculent dans le visage
tu parles d’une image aux chaussettes tire-bouchonnées
la faïence n’a pas de pli, le corps est celui des étapes précédentes, avec le rire qui fut le son qu’elle produisit
il y a le scandale d’une possession, le choc invité à ma table ; puis une autre partie commence
nous nous occuperons du squelette, petit
je ne suis plus celle que j’étais comme je fus l’enfant d’une seule fois
la ronde des chaises, assorties, vides, sur lesquelles le programme n’assoit rien, refait la disparition dont nous tenons les premiers rôles
translated_poem:
we get used to writings leaning
we get used to writings leaning where there are no longer children, now that they’ve grown up and their eyes recede into their faces
you talk of an image with corkscrewed socks
the piece of earthenware has no crease, the body is that of previous stages, with a laugh that was the sound she produced
there is the scandal of a possession, the shock invited to my table; then another part begins
we're taking care of the skeleton, dear
i am no longer the one i was when i was the child of a single time
the circle of chairs, matching, empty, on which the program sits nothing down, recreates the disappearance where we play the leading roles
translated_by_TA:
one adjusts to slanted scriptures where there are no longer children, when they have grown up and their eyes recede into their face
you speak of an image with bunched-up socks
the faience has no crease, the body is from previous stages, with the laughter that was the sound it produced
there is the scandal of possession, the shock invited to my table; then another part begins
we will deal with the skeleton, small one
I am no longer who I was, as I was the child of a single time
the circle of chairs, matched, empty, on which the program seats nothing, re-enacts the disappearance of which we play the leading roles

original_poem:
si souvent qu’ils s’ennuient les enfants devraient dire : nous sommes les figurants d’un parage de fiction. nous nous pré-promenons
allons-y gaiement, allons-y, ne refaisons pas les fous
j’ai reçu la bande audio d’un copain, à la fois proche et ses gestes sont les miens, quand aux miens je m’accorde à ce que nous avons de commun
si souvent qu’ils s’ennuient les enfants devraient dire : nous sommes les figurants d’un parage de fiction
translated_poem:
they get bored so often
they get bored so often the children should say: we are the extras in a fictive lineage. we go out for a pre-stroll
let's go joyfully, let's go, let's not fool around
i received the audio from a friend, both near and his gestures are mine, when to mine i harmonize with what we have in common
they get bored so often the children should say: we are the extras in a fictive lineage.
translated_by_TA:
Often as they get bored, children should say: we are the extras in a framing of fiction. We stroll aimlessly, let's go cheerfully, let's go, let's not repeat the fools
I received the audio tape from a friend, both close and his gestures are mine, as I agree with what we have in common
Often as they get bored, children should say: we are the extras in a framing of fiction.

original_poem:
elle
donne-moi un nom, ulysse
donne-moi un nom que je puisse t’attendre
je serai là, il y aura un miroir
et nous parlerons de toi, moi et l’autre au-dedans du miroir
je la rejoindrai là, toujours un peu de biais, au bord d’une chaise, à la manière des oiseaux
avec la douleur dans ma cuisse pour ne pas me perdre de ce côté du miroir
le matin je porterai mes boucles d’oreilles
je les garderai peut-être même au lit si tu devais me surprendre au milieu de la nuit
mais si je n’ai pas de nom comment savoir qui d’elle ou de moi veille?
translated_poem:
give me a name, ulysses
she
give me a name, ulysses
give me a name so that i can wait for you
i’ll be here, the mirror, there
and we’ll speak of you, i and the other in the mirror
i’ll join her there, a little slant, on the edge of a chair, the way birds do
the ache in my thigh keeps me from losing myself to that side of the mirror
in the morning i’ll wear my earrings
i may even wear them to bed should you surprise me in the night
but if i have no name how will i know which of us, her or me, is waiting?
translated_by_TA:
she
gives me a name, ulysses
gives me a name so i can wait for you
i will be there, there will be a mirror
and we will talk about you, me and the other within the mirror
i will join her there, always a bit askew, by the edge of a chair, like birds
with the pain in my thigh so as not to lose myself on this side of the mirror
in the morning i will wear my earrings
i might even keep them on in bed if you were to catch me in the middle of the night
but if i have no name how will one know who is watching, her or me?

original_poem:
la vierge de miséricorde
tout, maintenant,
bien au chaud
sous ton manteau léger,
presque rien que de brume et de broderie,
madone de miséricorde de la neige.
contre ton corps
dorment, nus,
les êtres et les choses, et tes doigts
voilent de leur clarté ces paupières closes.
translated_poem:
the virgin of mercy
all, now,
nice and warm
under your light cloak,
almost nothing but mist and embroidery,
madonna of mercy of the snow.
against your body
beings and things
sleep, naked, and your fingers
shade those closed eyelids from their light.
translated_by_TA:
The virgin of mercy
all, now,
well warm
under your light cloak,
almost nothing but mist and embroidery,
madonna of mercy of the snow.
against your body
sleep, naked,
the beings and things, and your fingers
veil with their brightness these closed eyelids.

original_poem:
de natura rerum
lucrèce le savait:
ouvre le coffre,
tu verras, il est plein de neige
qui tourbillonne.
et parfois deux flocons
se rencontrent, s’unissent,
ou bien l’un se détourne, gracieusement
dans son peu de mort.
d’où vient qu’il fasse clair
dans quelques mots
quand l’un n’est que la nuit,
l’autre, qu’un rêve ?
d’où viennent ces deux ombres
qui vont, riant,
et l’une emmitouflée
d’une laine rouge ?
translated_poem:
de natura rerum
lucretius knew it:
open the chest
and you will see that it’s full of swirling
snow.
and sometimes two flakes
meet, combine,
or else one turns aside gracefully
in its small death.
where does the idea come from that it’s clear
in a few words
when the one is only the night,
the other only a dream?
where do those two shadows come from
going along smiling,
and the one muffled up
in red wool?
translated_by_TA:
From the nature of things
Lucretius knew well:
Open the chest,
You'll see, it is full of snow
That swirls around.
And sometimes two flakes
Meet, unite,
Or one gracefully
Turns aside in its little death.
Where does the clarity come from
In a few words
When one is just night,
The other, a dream?
Where do these two shadows come from
That go, laughing,
And one wrapped up
In red wool?

original_poem:
juste avant l’aube
je regarde à travers les vitres, et je crois comprendre
qu’il a cessé de neiger. une flaque bleue
s’étend, brillante un peu, devant les arbres,
d’une paroi à l’autre de la nuit.
je sors.
je descends précautionneusement l’escalier de bois
dont les marches sont nivelées par la neige fraîche.
le froid cerne et pénètre mes chevilles,
il semble que l’esprit en soit plus clair,
qui perçoit mieux le silence des choses.
dort-il encore
dans l’enchevêtrement du tas de bois
serré sous la fenêtre,
le chipmunk, notre voisin simple,
ou est-il déjà à errer dans les crissements et le froid?
je vois d’infimes marques devant la porte.
translated_poem:
just before dawn
just before dawn
i look through the window, and i think i understand
that it has stopped snowing. a blue puddle
spreads, sparkling a little, in front of the trees,
from one end to the other of the night.
i go out.
i cautiously go down the wooden stairs
where the fresh snow has levelled the steps.
the cold surrounds and penetrates my ankles,
it seems that my mind is clearer because of it,
which perceives better the silence of things.
he is still sleeping
in the confusion of the pile of wood
ricked under the window,
the chipmunk, our simple neighbour,
or is he already roaming in the crunchy cold?
i see tiny marks in front of the door.
translated_by_TA:
just before dawn
I look through the windows, and I believe I understand
that it has stopped snowing. a blue pool
stretches, somewhat shiny, before the trees,
from one wall to the other of the night.
I go out.
I cautiously descend the wooden stairs
whose steps are evened by the fresh snow.
The cold bites and penetrates my ankles,
it seems that the mind is clearer,
which perceives the silence of things better.
is he still sleeping
in the jumble of the woodpile
pressed against the window,
the chipmunk, our simple neighbor,
or is he already wandering in the squeaks and the cold?
I see minute marks before the door.

original_poem:
l’été encore
j’avance dans la neige, j’ai fermé
les yeux, mais la lumière sait franchir
les paupières poreuses, et je perçois
que dans mes mots c’est encore la neige
qui tourbillonne, se resserre, se déchire.
neige,
lettre que l’on retrouve et que l’on déplie,
et l’encre en a blanchi et dans les signes
la gaucherie de l’esprit est visible
qui ne sait qu’en enchevêtrer les ombres claires.
et on essaye de lire, on ne comprend pas
qui s’intéresse à nous dans la mémoire,
sinon que c’est l’été encore; et que l’on voit
sous les flocons les feuilles, et la chaleur
monter du sol absent comme une brume.
translated_poem:
summer again
i go through the snow. i closed
my eyes, but the light can still get through
my porous eyelids, and i perceive
that in my words it’s still the snow
that swirls, thickens, bursts.
snow,
a letter that we find and unfold,
and the ink on it has faded and in the marks
the clumsiness of the wit is visible
which can only muddle up its sharp shadows.
and we try to read, we don’t understand
who is interested in us in memory,
except that it’s summer again; and we see
under the flakes the leaves, and the heat
rise from the missing sun like a mist.
translated_by_TA:
summer still
I advance through the snow, my eyes closed
but light knows how to penetrate
the porous eyelids, and I perceive
that in my words it is still the snow
that swirls, tightens, tears apart.
snow,
letter that is unfolded and refolded,
and the ink has turned white and in the signs
the awkwardness of the mind is visible
which only knows how to entangle clear shadows.
and one tries to read, one does not understand
who cares about us in memory,
except that it is summer still; and one sees
under the flakes the leaves, and the warmth
rising from the absent ground like a mist.

original_poem:
la charrue
cinq heures. la neige encore. j’entends des voix
à l’avant du monde.
une charrue
comme une lune au troisième quartier
brille, mais la recouvre
la nuit d’un pli de la neige.
et cet enfant
a toute la maison pour lui, désormais. il va
d’une fenêtre à l’autre. il presse
ses doigts contre la vitre. il voit
des gouttes se former là ou il cesse
d’en pousser la buée vers le ciel qui tombe.
translated_poem:
the plough
five o’clock. snow again. i hear voices
in the front of the world.
a plough
like a moon in the third quarter
shines, but the night
covers it with a layer of snow.
and this child
has the whole house to himself, from now on. he goes
from one window to another. he presses
his fingers against the glass. he sees
drops form where he stops
pushing the mist towards the falling sky.
translated_by_TA:
The Plow
Five o'clock. Snow still. I hear voices
at the forefront of the world.
A plow
like a moon in its third quarter
shines, but night
is covered by a fold of snow.
And this child
has the whole house to himself now. He goes
from one window to the other. He presses
his fingers against the glass. He sees
drops forming where he stops
pushing the condensation towards the falling sky.

original_poem:
les pommes
et que faut-il penser
de ces pommes jaunes?
hier, elles étonnaient, d’attendre ainsi, nues
après la chute des feuilles,
aujourd’hui elles charment
tant leurs épaules
sont, modestement, soulignées
d’un ourlet de neige.
translated_poem:
the apples
and what must we think
of these yellow apples?
yesterday, they astonished, waiting like this, naked
after the leaves had fallen,
today they charm
as their shoulders
are modestly accented
with an edging of snow.
translated_by_TA:
the apples
and what to think
of these yellow apples?
yesterday they amazed, to wait thus, naked
after the fall of the leaves,
today they charm
so much their shoulders
are, modestly, outlined
with a hem of snow.

original_poem:
la parure
il neige. âme, que voulais-tu
que tu n’aies eu de naissance éternelle?
vois, tu as là
pour la mort même une robe de fête.
une parure comme à l’adolescence,
de celles que l’on prend à mains soucieuses
car l’étoffe en est transparente et reste près
des doigts qui la déploient dans la lumière,
on sait qu’elle est fragile comme l’amour.
mais des corolles, des feuilles y sont brodées,
et déjà la musique se fait entendre
dans la salle voisine, illuminée.
une ardeur mystérieuse te prend la main.
tu vas, le coeur battant, dans la grande neige.
translated_poem:
finery
it’s snowing. soul, did you expect
to have eternal birth?
see, you have there
even a party dress for death.
finery like in adolescence,
of those that we take in anxious hands
as the fabric of it is transparent and remains near
fingers that open it out in the light,
we know that it’s as fragile as love.
but corollas and leaves are embroidered there,
and already the music can be heard
in the neighbouring room, where the lights are.
a mysterious ardour takes your hand.
you go, your heart pounding, into the big snow.
translated_by_TA:
The adornment
It snows. Soul, what did you want
That you did not have an eternal birth?
See, you have there
For death itself a party dress.
An adornment like in adolescence,
Of those that one takes with worried hands
For the fabric is transparent and remains close
To the fingers that unfold it in the light,
One knows that it is fragile like love.
But there are little flowers, leaves embroidered there,
And already the music can be heard
In the nearby hall, illuminated.
A mysterious fervor takes your hand.
You go, your heart beating, in the great snow.

original_poem:
le peu d’eau
à ce flocon
qui sur ma main se pose, j’ai désir
d’assurer l’éternel
en faisant de ma vie, de ma chaleur,
de mon passé, de ces jours d’à présent,
un instant simplement: cet instant-ci, sans bornes.
mais déjà il n’est plus
qu’un peu d’eau, qui se perd
dans la brume des corps qui vont dans la neige.
translated_poem:
the little bit of water
this snowflake
that alights on my hand, i wish
to fix it as eternal
in making of my life, my heat,
my past, these present days,
simply a moment, this very moment, limitless.
but already it is only
a little bit of water getting lost
in the mist of the flakes going into the snow.
translated_by_TA:
the little water
to this snowflake
that on my hand rests, I have desire
to assure the eternal
by making of my life, my warmth,
my past, these days of now,
an instant simply: this instant, boundless.
but already it is no more
than little water, which gets lost
in the mist of bodies that walk in the snow.

original_poem:
le jardin
il neige.
sous les flocons la porte
ouvre enfin au jardin
de plus que le monde.
j’avance. mais se prend
mon écharpe à du fer
rouillé, et se déchire
en moi l’étoffe du songe.
translated_poem:
the garden
it’s snowing.
under the snowflakes the gate
finally opens to the garden
of more than the world.
i go forward. but my scarf
gets caught on rusty
iron and tears
in me the fabric of the dream.
translated_by_TA:
The Garden
It snows.
Under the flakes, the door
finally opens to the garden
more than the world.
I advance. But my scarf
catches on rusted iron
and the fabric of my dream tears within me.

original_poem:
le miroir
hier encore
les nuages passaient
au fond noir de la chambre.
mais à présent le miroir est vide.
neiger
se désenchevêtre du ciel.
translated_poem:
the mirror
yesterday again
the clouds were passing
at the far dark end of the room.
but just now the mirror is empty.
snowing
the untangling of the sky.
translated_by_TA:
The Mirror
Yesterday still
The clouds passed
At the back of the dark room.
But now the mirror is empty.
Snow
Untangling itself from the sky.

original_poem:
la grande neige
première neige tôt ce matin. l’ocre, le vert
se réfugient sous les arbres.
seconde, vers midi. ne demeure
de la couleur
que les aiguilles de pins
qui tombent elles aussi plus dru parfois que la neige.
puis, vers le soir,
le fléau de la lumière s’immobilise.
les ombres et les rêves ont même poids.
un peu de vent
écrit du bout du pied un mot hors du monde.
translated_poem:
the big snow
first snow early this morning. the ochre, the green
take refuge under the trees.
second, around noon. no colour
remains
except the pine needles
that sometimes fall thicker than the snow.
then toward evening,
the curse of the light comes to an end.
shadows and dreams have the same weight.
a little wind
writes with the tip of its toe a word outside the world.
translated_by_TA:
the great snow
first snow early this morning. the ochre, the green
seek refuge under the trees.
second, around noon. no color remains
but the pine needles
which also fall, sometimes even more heavily than the snow.
then, towards evening,
the scourge of light comes to a standstill.
shadows and dreams have the same weight.
a bit of wind
writes with the tip of its foot a word outside the world.

original_poem:
l’exercice simple à son fiancé
à son nouvel l’appartement des terres
peut pas sonner le triomphe lys blancs
où le ranger l’adresse égare
tout corps voisin du sien
avoir vu sa créature à l’intérieur
d’un format elle était on la refait
à la sphère plus qu’à la première
dans les fils et qu’il est né dedans
tenue de tout à l’heure.
translated_poem:
flirt formula 01
the simple exercise to his beloved
to his newest the earthly dwelling
cannot ring white lily triumphant
where to put him address misplaces
all bodies nearby
having seen one’s own being inside
a format she was so let’s do it again
within a globe more than the first
in the filaments his being born
held over once more.
translated_by_TA:
The simple exercise to his fiance
to his new apartment in the fields
can't sound the triumph white lilies
where to put the lost address
every body near his
having seen his creature inside
in a format she was remade
to the sphere more than the first one
in the wires and that it was born inside
the attire of just now.

original_poem:
pour achever / la beauté du monde /
il faut que la lumière /
étreigne la pavane / des ombres sur tes lèvres /
translated_poem:
for the world’s beauty
for the world’s beauty / to be complete /
light must embrace /
the pavane of shadows / passing across your lips /
translated_by_TA:
to complete / the beauty of the world /
light must / embrace the pavane / of shadows on your lips /

original_poem:
conte
un soir où nous avions mis une seule ceinture
tu me chuchotais un conte à l’oreille de neige
et me disais je suis émue
et nous avions enjambé déjà plusieurs grands intervalles
fait des arches d’absence plus grandes que celles d’avignon
et sommes revenus à nous par des gués en crue
translated_poem:
tale
one evening as we were wearing a single belt
you whispered a tale in my ear of snow
and said i’m moved
and we had already stridden over several wide intervals
made of arches of absence wider than those at avignon
and came back to ourselves by rising fords
translated_by_TA:
Translate the following poem from fr_XX to en_XX:

remember
one evening when we had put on a single belt
you whispered a tale to my ear of snow
and told me i am moved
and we had already leaped over several large intervals
built arches of absence larger than those of avignon
and we returned to ourselves by means of flood-swollen fords

original_poem:
bord
pourquoi revient cette formule aimée
“au bord du monde encore une fois”
qu’est ce bord, qu’est ce ‘bord’, être-au-bord
la bordure chez baudelaire et
la terrasse des princes de rimbaud
avec vue sur le monde et le tout comme
ayant passé par ici qui repassera par là
translated_poem:
edge
why this loved formula comes back
“at the edge of the world once more”
what is edge, what is ‘edge’, being on edge
the edge in baudelaire and
the princes’ terrace in rimbaud
with a view of the world and all as if
come and come again
translated_by_TA:
edge
why does this beloved formula return
"on the edge of the world once again"
what is this edge, what is this 'edge', being-on-the-edge
the border in baudelaire and
the terrace of the princes of rimbaud
with a view of the world and everything as if
having passed here who will pass again there

original_poem:
c’est entre nous
l’air entre les mains salut
et la main entre les saluts
et le salut par intervalle
rien avec rien jouant à
s’envoyer la belle apparition
translated_poem:
it is between us
it is between us
air between the hands wave
and the hand between waves
and waving by intervals
nothing with nothing playing at
laying the fair apparition
translated_by_TA:
It's between us
The air between the salut hands
And the hand between the salutations
And the salutation by interval
Nothing with nothing playing to
Send the beautiful appearance

Note: The translation provided is a creative interpretation aiming to capture the essence and flow of the original French poem.

original_poem:
le plaisir
confinait à
l’interdit
la mâchoire
du
mort
bloquée
après
coup
le fils
étendu
lumière
artificielle
celui qui pense
désormais
sans respirer
translated_poem:
pleasure was
pleasure was
close to
the forbidden
the dead
man’s
jaw
locked
after-
wards
the son
prone
artificial
light
he who thinks
henceforth
without breathing
translated_by_TA:
pleasure
was confined to
the forbidden
the jaw
of the
dead
locked
afterwards
the son
stretched
artificial light
he who thinks
nowadays
without breathing

original_poem:
20 novembre 2001
rien
ne me
retient
porte
et fenêtres
closes
rue
étroite
et
vide
trois années
de deuil
translated_poem:
20 november 2001
20 november 2001
nothing
holds me
back
door
and windows
closed
street
narrow
and
empty
three years
of mourning
translated_by_TA:
20 November 2001
nothing
holds me
door
and closed windows
narrow
and empty street
three years
of mourning

original_poem:
il y a
il y a la route avec ses trous,
il y a partout cette menace immense
qu’on m’appelle, qu’on me dise mon défaut,
je m’inclinerai jusqu’à terre.
translated_poem:
there is the road
there is the road with its pot-holes,
everywhere there is this immense menace
that they summon me, that they tell me of my flaw,
i will bow down all the way to the earth.
translated_by_TA:
there is
there is the road with its holes,
there is everywhere this immense threat
that they call me, that they tell me my fault,
I will bow down to the ground.

original_poem:
soleil
soleillot
qui courait sur la vitre
qu’il chantait
qu’il lisait
le corps astral
de la verge
en vertu du principe
de non coïncidence de soi et soi
translated_poem:
sun
sun
sunny boy
running on the window
he read
he sang
the heavenly body
of the penis
in virtue of the principle
of non coincidence of self and self
translated_by_TA:
sun
small sun
which ran on the glass
that it sang
that it read
the astral body
of the rod
in virtue of the principle
of non-coincidence of self and self

original_poem:
elle
quitte
la maison
elle
se
retrouve
dans la rue
la course
l’entraîne
vers un désert
le pont
du fleuve
translated_poem:
she
she
leaves
the house
she
finds
herself
in the street
the race
sweeps her
to a desert
the bridge
on the river
translated_by_TA:
she
leaves
the house
she
finds herself
on the street
the chase
drags her
towards a desert
the bridge
of the river

original_poem:
un arbre…
un arbre et puis un arbre et puis
le froid
je ne veux plus que cet aveugle
me guide
comme on est seul
quand on marche depuis toujours
un arbre et puis
pas même un arbre, une distance
d’autres, je les aimais,
sont loin.
translated_poem:
a tree
a tree and then a tree and then
the cold
i don’t want that blind one
to guide me anymore
how alone one is
when one has been walking from the outset
a tree and then
not even a tree, remote
others i loved, are far,
they are far.
translated_by_TA:
A tree...
a tree and then a tree and then
the cold
I want no longer this blind one
to guide me
how alone one is
when one walks always
a tree and then
not even a tree, a distance
others, I loved them,
are far away.

original_poem:
peut-etre qu’il reviendra
peut-être qu’il reviendra, le fou, qu’il
me prendra par l’épaule
comme hier, quand je voulais mourir
dans un trou
peut-être qu’il dira, mon oncle, ne me laisse
pas sur la route
emmène-moi où les paroles ne déchirent plus.
translated_poem:
maybe he\'ll come back
maybe he’ll come back, he’ll
grasp me by the shoulder
just like yesterday, when i wanted to die
in a ditch
maybe he’ll say, nunc, don’t leave me
on the road
lead me where words no longer scourge.
translated_by_TA:
Maybe he will come back
Maybe he will come back, the fool, that
he will take me by the shoulder
as yesterday, when I wanted to die
in a hole
maybe he will say, my uncle, don't leave
me on the road
take me where words no longer tear apart.
